--- Comment #1 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Thank you.  I agree we should not change the code (at least not lightly), and I
agree 
on your reasoning that the *upper tail* probability should rather be one here.

Hence, I also agree on your classification as _Documentation_  "bug".
Before doing so, we should possibly survey the situation a bit more broadly.
E.g., the  Beta distribution of course also has point masses in boundary cases,
at x =  1/2, or 0, or 1 (or both)
```
> pbeta(0:1, 0,0)
[1] 0.5 1.0
> pbeta(1/2, Inf,Inf)
[1] 1
> pbeta(0, 2, Inf)
[1] 1
> pbeta(1, Inf, 2)
[1] 1
> pbeta(0, 1/2, Inf)
[1] 1
```
etc, and it seems that here they are treated differently ... 
(for good reasons, possibly)?

Maybe the documentation should emphasize that  F(x) = Pr(X <= x)  is only
guaranteed when F(x) is continuous {{which it is, in our cases, exactly iff
there are no point masses}}.  OTOH, I don't even know if probability theory is
"clear" here, i.e., when the CDF is not continuous.
(Note that a double precision implementation of any function is never truly
continuous, as it is only defined on a finite set; hence principles such as
"cad.lag." are typically less useful here).
